column2: About the job Its a global virtual hospital. We are reimagining the delivery of critical care through patient-centric solutions. We use our advanced technology, designed and developed in-house, to increase access to care, all across the globe. It has been radically transforming the delivery of critical care by impacting thousands of patients across India and enabling them to receive high-quality care irrespective of their location and is moving towards mainstreaming this model globally. Our Care Center, based in Bangalore, is staffed 24/7 by a highly qualified and trained critical care team that includes super-specialist doctors, nurses, dieticians, and pharmacologists. The clinical team uses our proprietary platform, RADAR, to connect to hospital ICUs to oversee and manage the care of critically ill patients across multiple regions. RADAR, built by our team of technology experts, incorporates automation, computer vision, real-time video, and data analytics to help expert care providers connect to and provide care to patients. We have cared for nearly 90,000 intensive care patients across 21 states in India and saved numerous lives. column2: Fortis Healthcare Ltd is looking for Senior Resident Critical Care - Neuro to join our dynamic team and embark on a rewarding career journey          Patient Management    : You oversee the care of patients with a wide range of neurological conditions such as traumatic brain injury, stroke, epilepsy, neurosurgical emergencies, and neuromuscular disorders. This involves performing comprehensive assessments, interpreting diagnostic tests (e.g., CT scans, MRI), and developing individualized treatment plans.                Multidisciplinary Collaboration    : Critical care is inherently multidisciplinary, and collaboration with various healthcare professionals is essential. You work closely with neurologists, neurosurgeons, nurses, respiratory therapists, pharmacists, and other specialists to coordinate care and optimize patient outcomes.                Advanced Monitoring and Intervention    : In the neurocritical care setting, you utilize advanced monitoring techniques to assess neurological status, intracranial pressure (ICP), cerebral perfusion, and other physiological parameters. Ventilator Management    : Many neurocritical care patients require mechanical ventilation due to conditions such as traumatic brain injury or neuromuscular weakness. As a Senior Resident, you are responsible for managing ventilator settings, optimizing oxygenation and ventilation, and preventing complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia and barotrauma.                Seizure Management    : Seizures and status epilepticus are common neurological emergencies encountered in the ICU. You are trained to recognize and manage seizures promptly using antiepileptic medications and other interventions to prevent further neurological injury.                End-of-Life Care and Ethical Considerations    : In situations where patients have severe neurological injuries or poor prognoses, you provide compassionate end-of-life care and support to patients and their families. You may also be involved in discussions regarding goals of care, advance directives, and ethical dilemmas surrounding life-sustaining treatments.

column2: A Senior Specialist in Critical Care is a highly trained medical professional who has specialized expertise in managing and providing intensive care to critically ill patients     They are typically at an advanced stage of their career and have extensive experience in critical care medicine         Here are some key responsibilities of a Senior Specialist in Critical Care:         Patient Management: Senior Specialists in Critical Care are responsible for the overall management of critically ill patients in the intensive care unit (ICU)     They assess patients, interpret diagnostic tests, and develop comprehensive treatment plans     They closely monitor patients' vital signs, response to therapy, and adjust treatment regimens as necessary     Decision-making: They make critical decisions regarding patient care, including the use of life support measures, ventilator management, hemodynamic support, and administration of medications     They analyze complex clinical data, collaborate with other specialists, and provide guidance to the healthcare team to optimize patient outcomes     Emergency Response: Senior Specialists in Critical Care are trained to handle medical emergencies and crises that may occur in the ICU     They lead resuscitation efforts during cardiac arrests, manage acute respiratory distress, and provide rapid interventions to stabilize patients in life-threatening situations     Procedures and Interventions: They perform a variety of procedures and interventions necessary for critical care management     These may include endotracheal intubation, central line insertion, arterial line placement, chest tube insertion, bronchoscopy, and other specialized procedures     Multidisciplinary Team Collaboration: Senior Specialists in Critical Care work closely with a multidisciplinary team, including attending physicians, nurses, respiratory therapists, pharmacists, and other healthcare professionals     They collaborate to develop and implement individualized care plans, ensure effective communication, and coordinate the delivery of comprehensive critical care
